awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Life-Long Learning for Motion Planning by Robots in Human Populated Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Long-term, safe interaction in human-populated environments is essential to the widespread adoption and continued deployment of robotics. Accordingly, an important aspect of behaving safely is the ability to use one's observations and past experiences to set realistic expectations about others' behaviors, operating in such a way that minimizes the risk of failure or causing harm. Just as humans are capable of adapting their behavior to changing circumstances and understanding possible failures, robots must similarly understand risks and adapt their behaviors to safely complete tasks in densely populated or dynamic environments. To enable these capabilities, this project will develop methods to provide mobile robots with the ability to build their own models of activity-based risk and human behaviors, using them to mitigate dangerous or risk-prone scenarios in the presence of uncertainty. These methods are broadly applicable across service robots, manufacturing robots, and close-quarters collaborative robots, enabling the effective and safe integration of such systems into human environments that have otherwise been inaccessible for enhancement or improvement through robotic automation. By contributing toward making such applications possible, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society at large, while simultaneously contributing to the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing on grounds of safety and efficiency through advanced and flexible automation. This work involves contributions from many complementary areas of research, including robotics, human factors, manufacturing, and computer science through both academic and industry collaborations. 

To address challenges in safe, life-long learning as applied to long-term robot operation, this research focuses on the development of novel algorithms for self-supervised human-aware motion planning and context-aware trajectory optimization. Advancing the state-of-the-art in self-supervised learning through self-determined curriculum development and learning through experiences collected during live deployments, the work will additionally develop new transfer learning techniques to generalize experiences and behavioral models across contexts. Robots incorporating these research products will be able to learn to anticipate and mitigate risks and potential failure modes during task execution in uncertain environments by leveraging their own self-collected knowledge. This award targets fundamental advances in social navigation and task execution by integrating human motion modeling and robot motion planning with contextual understanding, achieving applicable and real-world grounded results through long-term mobile robot deployments in public spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The integration of robots into daily life, both in public spaces and in the workplace, is becoming increasingly prevalent. From personal assistance to performing complex tasks in factories, robots have the potential to improve our quality of life and producitivity tremendously. However, for robots to become truly efficient, safe, and accessible, it is necessary to develop robust capabilities within both robot social navigation and risk-aware motion planning.

At the core of robot social navigation is the ability to understand and interpret human social cues, enabling robots to smoothly navigate shared spaces with people. This research area seeks to develop robots that can seamlessly integrate into our lives without causing confusion or discomfort. By understanding human behavior and expectations, robots can adapt to our social norms, empowering them to be better collaborators. Risk-aware motion planning, on the other hand, focuses on enabling robots to identify and respond to potential dangers in their environment while still maintaining productive progress toward their goals. By equipping robots with the ability to predict and avoid hazards, we can ensure the safety of both humans and the machines themselves. This is especially crucial in complex or unpredictable environments, where robots must navigate around dynamic obstacles, anticipate human movement, and adapt to sudden changes. The combined research on robot social navigation and risk-aware motion planning is vital for creating a world where humans and robots coexist in shared spaces. By advancing this knowledge, we can develop robots that not only enhance our lives but also ensure our safety and well-being.

Through this effort we have produced a novel, real-time planner for navigation amongst pedestrians that is more tolerant and responsive to incorrect predictions of human movements than competing solutions, ensuring robot safety when operating under uncertainty. We have also developed a novel mapping technique capable of producing durable maps that are functional despite changes over time, an essential capability for robots that operate on long timescales. Further, novel social navigation algorithms produced through this award targeting autonomous robot navigation were applied in new robotics contexts, including an assistive robotics application for the visually impaired, improving human capabilities by leveraging the same algorithmic foundations that make robots safe. Finally, this award enabled the development of a novel, rapid constrained motion planning technique to deliver safer, near real-time performance for safety critical motion planning, providing an efficient solution to a previously unsolved problem of motion planning across time-varying constraints (the "Intersection-Dependent Sequential Manifold Planning Problem"). To improve the usability of these advances by the community and those who interact with these robots, we have also developed and validated novel visualization interfaces.

This project has produced seven peer-reviewed publications and one doctoral thesis, with further papers in development. The advances achieved over the period of performance for this project have been incorporated into the open access "Introduction to Autonomous Robots: Mechanisms, Sensors, Actuators, and Algorithms" textbook published by MIT Press, written to be accessible to audiences ranging from the undergraduate through PhD level. Multiple undergraduate students were involved in this research, launching their research careers and providing them with the opportunity and training to materially contribute to the state of the art in robotics.
